Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Simulation-Based Optimization Techniques For Urban Transportation Problems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award is the development of computationally efficient simulation-based optimization techniques for three types of urban transportation problems: (i) dynamic, (ii) large-scale, and (iii) reliable. The techniques enable state-of-the-art urban traffic simulators to address a variety of continuous, nonlinear, constrained and high-dimensional optimization problems. They combine ideas from the fields of metamodel simulation-based optimization, transient finite capacity queueing theory and traffic flow theory. Their performance is evaluated by considering urban traffic management problems for three road networks in the United States, Europe and Asia.

This project will be carried out in collaboration with a transportation agency in the United States. The techniques will support their ongoing planning and operational efforts. Numerous transportation agencies and consultants around the world use these traffic simulation tools to inform their planning and operations decisions. The techniques will enable practitioners to identify transportation strategies that provide both local and network-wide improvements. If successful, these techniques contribute to improve the management of transportation systems, mitigate peak-hour congestion, and thereby reduce its economic and environmental impacts. They also contribute to providing an improved urban mobility experience by identifying traffic management strategies that lead to more reliable transportation services. Enabling the use of microscopic simulators to efficiently identify network design improvements may also lead to substantial savings for infrastructure projects. The ideas and results of this project will be discussed with the main simulation software developers. Through various educational activities, this project will involve, encourage and train underrepresented students in conducting engineering research and problem solving.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This work has involved undergraduate students, PhD students, faculty and transportation practitioners. It has gvien students the opportunity to present their research both internall at MIT and externally at various international conferences. The mentoring and communication skills of PhD students have also been enhanced through their experience as Teaching Assistants. The students have worked closely with practitioners, gvien them first hand exposure to real problems. The PI has shared the outcomes of this project through academic talks (plenary and non-plenary), talks for the broader public and talks for industry stakeholders.

The design of mobility services that fulfill the needs of thousands of heterogeneous users distributed across large urban areas requires tackling high-dimensional simulation-based optimization (problems. The techniques developed as part of this project enable this. More specifically, they enable for the first time high-resolution mobility data and models, obtained and formulated at the scale of individuals and vehicles, to be used to optimize the performance of mobility systems at the scale of entire cities. The various case studies show how, for the first time, high-resolution large-scale mobility simulators to be used efficiently for optimization. High-resolution models embed a detailed description of the behavior of individual travelers, while large-scale network optimization allows us to account for the metropolitan scale impact of individual mobility decisions. Combining these two enables the design of next generation mobility services that are both user-centric and sustainable. Given the critical energy, environmental, and economic sustainability issues posed by urban mobility, this work has great potential for impact on society.

This work has proposed algorithms to tackle continuous SO problems that are: high-dimensional, dyanamic, and real-time. It has also proposed methods for high-dimensional discrete SO problems. The proposed methods combine how ideas from various research communities, such as mathematical programming, queueing theory, traffic flow theory, demand modeling.
